description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5r7qr","text":"This protocol is a practical guide for preparing acute coronal slices from the midbrain of young adult mice for electrophysiology experiments. It describes two different sets of solutions with their respective incubation strategies and two alternative procedures for brain extraction: decapitation under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia and intracardial perfusion with artificial cerebrospinal fluid under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia. Slices can be prepared from wild-type mice as well as from mice that have been genetically modified or transfected with viral constructs to label subsets of cells. The preparation can be used to investigate the electrophysiological properties of midbrain neurons in combination with pharmacology, opto- and chemogenetic manipulations, and calcium imaging; which can be followed by morphological reconstruction, immunohistochemistry, or single-cell transcriptomics. The protocol also provides a detailed list of materials and reagents including the design for a low-cost and easy to assemble 3D printed slice recovery chamber, general advice for troubleshooting common issues leading to suboptimal slice quality, and some suggestions to ensure good maintenance of a patch-clamp rig.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6hp3j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7astu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1irg5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8dsi","text":"This protocol provides a step-by-step guide for obtaining acute coronal slices from the midbrain of young adult mice (4-12 weeks old). The following sections include instructions for preparing two different sets of solutions with their respective incubation strategies and two alternative procedures for brain extraction: decapitation under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia (Path A) and intracardial perfusion with artificial cerebrospinal fluid (ACSF) under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia (Path B).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cuveg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3vj7r","text":"Path A is the simpler of the two approaches: the solutions are easier to prepare and the brain extraction is preceded by terminal anaesthesia and decapitation. This makes Path A less technically challenging than Path B.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5mop4","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7ipgg","text":"Path B is more elaborated: it requires three solutions instead of two, there is an additional incubation step, and the decapitation and brain extraction are preceded by intracardial perfusion. Intracardially perfusing the animal with ice-cold slicing solution before extracting the brain is the best way to remove the blood out of the tissue by replacing it with the solution of your choice (e.g. low sodium and calcium and high magnesium and NMDG) to rapidly slow metabolic activity and reduce excitotoxicity.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1ajde","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"642qv","text":"Given its easier implementation, our recommendation is to initially follow Path A and assess the quality of the resulting slices. In our hands, this method provides good quality slices especially when used in younger animals (up to 7-8 weeks old). If the quality of the slices is found to be suboptimal, or if the experimental design requires using animals that have undergone stereotaxic surgery or are \u003e8 weeks old, our recommendation is to implement Path B and read Section 8 (Troubleshooting slice quality problems) for further suggestions. We have found that both the solutions (NMDG-HEPES slicing and HEPES holding) and the intracardial perfusion method used in Path B significantly improve the quality of the slices and the amount of healthy cells found in the tissue.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e4r5s","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5bin8","text":"Path A uses a sucrose-based slicing solution in which a proportion of NaCl has been replaced by sucrose. This reduces the sodium driving force, ensuring there is less entry of sodium into the cells and reducing excitotoxicity. Sodium phosphate and sodium bicarbonate are buffers that help maintain the pH within a physiological range. The low calcium / high magnesium ratio in the slicing solution reduces neurotransmitter release and activation of NMDA receptors, and thus maintains a low overall excitability of the brain tissue. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"enerl","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e0kfg","text":"The slicing solution in Path B has been optimised for adult brain tissue (Ting, et al., 2018). Using NMDG-Cl to completely replace NaCl helps eliminates sodium entry into the cells, which together with a low temperature and intracardial perfusion slows down metabolism and reduces excitotoxicity even more. The addition of 20 mM HEPES effectively provides stronger pH buffering in the physiological range and prevents excessive edema. Myo-inositol and sodium pyruvate provide additional entry points into cellular metabolism, whereas ascorbic acid, thiourea, and N-acetyl-L-cysteine (a cell-permeable glutathione precursor) help reduce oxidative stress.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c9lfk","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8389d","text":"In both cases, it is important to use purified water that is free of contaminants such as trace metals. Impurities like these are often found in distilled water sources and cause damage to the slices and can convert anti-oxidants such as ascorbate into pro-oxidants.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"adua4","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dd8fp","text":"Besides the composition of the slicing solution, the other main difference between paths A and B is that path B uses a holding solution where slices are kept until used for recording. The holding solution effectively acts as a bridge between the very protective properties of the NMDG-based slicing solution and the physiological concentrations of the recording solution. Together, all these improvements make Path B the most protective of both approaches.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6qp5d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s1r4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"59u6e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5d17k","text":"[Common for Path A and Path B - Get the experimental subject]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7geo7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aa0re","text":"Follow the guidelines in place at the home institution to source experimental animals. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj3ho","text":"If you require your animals to be in a particular age bracket for your experiment, plan accordingly. Note that the older the animal is, the more challenging the slicing procedure becomes and the more difficult it is to obtain good quality slices.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6spku","text":"Once you are ready to begin your experiment, fetch the cage and bring it to the area where you will prepare the slices. This includes regularly checking the weight of the scavenging filter (replace it with a new one if the limit is exceeded and properly dispose of the old one) as well as the levels of isoflurane in the anaesthetic system (top it up if running low).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cg80g","text":"This section describes two different procedures: decapitation under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia and intracardial perfusion with ACSF under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia. Both procedures are followed by brain extraction and allow the preparation of coronal slices. The choice of method and ACSF recipe will very likely differ across brain regions, and you may need to make slight modifications to reach the optimal version for your particular experiment. Some suggestions in that direction can be found in Section 8.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5l4e6","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2uhgq","text":"It is very important to plan ahead - not only do you need to prepare solutions (and foresee any shortages in salts, water, or any other consumable you need) in advance, but you also need to ensure you have the right animals (genotype wise) at the most appropriate age for your experiment. Although the considerations and specific directives with regards to experimental animals will vary across institutions and will depend on experimental design and available equipment, the following sections provide a detailed account of how we executed each step. We provide this highly specific details in the hope that someone wishing to implement this method from scratch will have an example of how each step was successfully carried out in another institution.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"86d5b","text":"[PATH A - Decapitation under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6o1uf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"375id","text":"Wear appropriate PPE: coat, mask, and gloves.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57aha","text":"Put a disposal bag in the glass beaker if you haven't done so already.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3lqk","text":"Pour some slush of slicing ACSF in the small 150 mL beaker. Get the beaker and the scissors for decapitation  to the area where you will perform the procedure.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arfmb","text":"Switch ON the oxygen flow from the pipe in the wall, and also turn ON the oxygen flow in the anaesthesia system to around 2 mL/min.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dq2g9","text":"Switch the scavenging system ON and double check a clean tissue paper is present on the floor of the anaesthetic chamber.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lrsq","text":"Turn the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber so that it is on the \"scavenging\" position before opening the isoflurane flow (the scavenging system is there to protect you from any isoflurane leaks).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqhp4","text":"Proceed to anaesthetise the mouse: open the animal cage and gently cup the mouse of your choice (we usually have ear marks to identify them when group housed) and transfer to the anaesthetic chamber. If possible, avoid picking up by the tail as this leads to stress. Once the animal is in the anaesthetic chamber, switch the isoflurane pump ON by turning the wheel to 5 mL/min. Turn the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber to the \"anaesthetise\" position. While you wait for the isoflurane to have its effect, close the animal cage and move below the hood, so that the remaining animals can't see the rest of the procedure.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk7l6","text":"Once the animal is under anaesthesia, open the chamber and check the reflexes by pinching the rear paw. If the anaesthesia levels are good, switch the isoflurane pump OFF and return the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber to \"scavenging\" position. Leave the scavenging system on for as long as you extract the brain.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgn1c","text":"Take the animal out, hold over the beaker containing the slush of slicing ACSF, and place the large scissors around the neck. With a swift cut, proceed to perform the decapitation, making sure the head falls inside the ice-cold and already bubbled slush of slicing ACSF. Place the carcass in the bag of the large beaker.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5a50g","text":"Quickly take the beaker to the vibratome area, making sure the head is completely immersed in the cold solution. The next steps are crucial and must be done as quickly as possible - ideally the time between decapitation and immersing the extracted brain in the slush of slicing ACSF should be less than 1 minute.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"efpvj","text":"[PATH B - Perfusion with ACSF under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dg7qo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ipif","text":"Wear appropriate PPE: coat, mask, and gloves.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adqdr","text":"Put a disposal bag in the glass beaker if you haven't done so already.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b9d8","text":"Pour some slush of slicing ACSF in the small 150 mL beaker. Get the beaker and the tools for dissection and decapitation (scissors for decapitation, scissors for skin, and forceps) to the area where you will perform the procedure.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjmp8","text":"Load a 20 mL syringe with slush of slicing ACSF and mount a small brown needle on it. Press to squirt a bit of liquid and make sure there are no air bubbles in the syringe.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8t7j2","text":"Get the tray and the silicon mat together with four sterile small brown needles, which you will use to pin the animal. Place the anaesthetic mask on the silicon mat. Remove the cap from the needles and stick them into the silicon mat.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbbfe","text":"Place the tools, syringe, and beaker on a piece of clean tissue paper next to the tray, ready for use.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bm6aj","text":"Switch ON the oxygen flow from the pipe in the wall, and also turn ON the flow in the anaesthesia system to around 2 mL/min.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j28l","text":"Switch the scavenging system ON and double check a clean tissue paper is present on the floor of the anaesthetic chamber.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5oohc","text":"Turn the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber so that it is on the \"scavenging\" position before opening the isoflurane flow (this system is there to protect you from any isoflurane leaks).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97lkf","text":"Proceed to anaesthetise the mouse: open the animal cage and gently cup the mouse of your choice (we usually have ear marks to identify them when group housed) and transfer to the anaesthetic chamber. If possible, avoid picking up by the tail as this leads to stress. Once the animal is in the anaesthetic chamber, switch the isoflurane pump ON by turning the wheel to 5 mL/min. Switch the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber to the \"anaesthetise\" position. While you wait for the isoflurane to have its effect, close the animal cage and move below the hood, so that the remaining animals can't see the rest of the procedure.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cb4r","text":"Once the animal is under anaesthesia, open the chamber and check the reflexes by pinching the rear paw. If the anaesthesia levels are good, turn the valve to change the anaesthesia circuit from the chamber to the mask and transfer the mouse to the silicon mat. Carefully place the mask around the snout, making sure it stays into position. Switch the valve to change the scavenging circuit from the chamber to the mask and turn the valve behind the anaesthetic chamber from \"anaesthetise\" to \"scavenging\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vn6t","text":"With the mask well placed and the mouse still under anaesthesia, check the reflexes again. If the anaesthesia levels are still good, proceed to pin the animal to the silicon mat with one needle in each paw.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hrpf","text":"Take the scissors with your dominant hand and the forceps with the other and proceed to make an incision on the skin at the level of the abdomen. Use the scissors to gain access to the abdominal cavity, and proceed to dissect up towards the rib cage until you see the diaphragm. Once you cut the diaphragm, the animal stops breathing properly and starts dying, so you need to be fast (otherwise perfusing will not be much of an improvement compared to decapitation). Carefully cut the diaphragm and cut around the rib cage until you see the heart. Use the forceps to lift the cut rib cage so you have good access to the heart. Carefully cut the right atrium - blood should start coming out. Quickly leave the scissors and get the syringe with the ice-cold slicing ACSF (squirt a bit of solution to ensure there are no bubbles in the tip). Use the forceps to position the heart and insert the needle in the left ventricle. Slowly empty the syringe without stopping, until all the solution has been used. If the perfusion works well, the liver should turn white and clean ACSF should be coming out the cut atrium towards the end.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9c8rb","text":"If you have a steady pulse and don't need the second hand to keep the syringe in place while perfusing, use it to remove the mask from the snout and switch the isoflurane pump OFF (leaving the scavenging system on). Sometimes during the perfusion some ACSF comes out of the snout - removing the mask ensures the solution doesn't end up in it.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6aga2","text":"Once the syringe is empty and the perfusion is complete, remove the needles pinning the animal to the silicon mat and take the big scissors. Carefully lift the mouse and hold over the beaker containing the remaining slush of slicing ACSF. Place the large scissors around the neck and, with a swift cut, proceed to perform the decapitation, making sure the head falls inside the ice-cold and already bubbled slush of slicing ACSF. Place the carcass in the bag of the large beaker.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78rg6","text":"If you haven't done so yet, switch the isoflurane pump OFF and leave the scavenging system on for as long as you extract the brain. After that, make sure you come back to change the valves back to the chamber circuit and leave the scavenging on for a bit longer. Remember to close the oxygen flow and the scavenger when you are done.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7aops","text":"Quickly take the beaker to the vibratome area, making sure the head is completely immersed in the cold solution. The next steps are crucial and must be done as quickly as possible - ideally the time between decapitation and immersing the extracted brain in the slush of slicing ACSF should be less than 1 minute.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1g0s7","text":"[Common for Path A and Path B - Brain extraction (\u003c1 min)]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":58}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6bj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ladr","text":"Pour some slush from the 400 mL beaker on ice (where the slush of slicing ACSF has been bubbling all this time) into the crystallizing dish. This is where you will keep immersing the head while doing the brain extraction, in order to keep it as cold as possible. Having a separate beaker for the extraction and decapitation also reduces the amount of blood carried over.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gnmd","text":"Take the head from the small beaker and place it in the crystallizing dish with clean slush.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9ot0","text":"Hold the head to ensure the skull is stable by applying pressure to the snout (adopt a sort of pinching position with the thumb and index that surrounds the snout and with the maximal pressure on the phalanges - never apply pressure to the skull itself, as you will compress and damage the brain). Place your middle finger beneath the lower jaw as a support. Importantly, you should ensure you have practiced this in advance (for instance, with a carcass or a 3D printed model of a mouse skull) - having a good and stable grip will be critical to extract the brain as quickly and safely as possible.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21pmn","text":"Use the medium size scissors to cut through the skin along the midline and expose the skull. Start at the back of the neck and make your way until the snout. Fully immerse the head in the ice-cold slush of slicing ACSF.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38pg3","text":"With the brain still immersed in the slush, switch to the small serrated scissors. Start to very carefully cut through the bone from the foramen magnum in the following sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95r49","text":"(1) The first two cuts will be to the sides, from the foramen magnum around the temporal bone until the zygomatic bone or the ear canal (surrounding the cerebellum). This two cuts (one to the right and one to the left) are very important as will reach the insertion of most meninges: making sure these are cut will prevent they slash through the brain and separate the cerebellum and inferior colliculus from the superior colliculus and periaqueductal gray.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ck79a","text":"(2) Next, once again insert the small serrated scissors in the foramen magnum and proceed to cut the skull along the midline suture from caudal to rostral until you reach the snout. Make sure you cut \"up\" when you advance with the scissors (never \"down\" towards the brain) to avoid pressing the bone against the tissue. Fully immerse the head in the ice-cold slush of slicing ACSF.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"flnd9","text":"(3) Finally, make two small cuts from the midline to the laterals at the level of the olfactory bulb. Fully immerse the head in the ice-cold slush of slicing ACSF.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6oob","text":"N.B: although you must be fast, it is also necessary to be very careful and to keep mechanical stress to the minimum - the midbrain is incredibly sensitive. In addition, as already mentioned above, always make the scissor cuts in the upper direction, so that instead of applying pressure to the skull you are lifting it away from the brain. In many cases, insufficient slice quality is due to problems at this very early stage.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bt15t","text":"With the brain still immersed in the slush, switch to the fine Dumont forceps. Very carefully lift each half of the skull and check if the dura mater is still stuck to the brain or if it instead lifts with the bone. If the dura is still stuck to the brain, make sure you carefully detach it by inserting the tip of the forceps right below it and moving the tip across the bone (from front to back). Do the same for both sides and make sure the meninges are out of the picture before proceeding. Fully immerse the head in the ice-cold slush of slicing ACSF. This is an essential step, if not done the remaining meninges can cut the entire brain when you lift the skull in the next step.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"art61","text":"With the brain still immersed in the slush, switch to the thick serrated forceps. Remove the skull by lifting the cut bone with the forceps while moving the hand that holds the head in the opposite direction. Do the same for the other side. Fully immerse the head in the ice-cold slush of slicing ACSF.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t4f8","text":"With the brain still immersed in the slush, take the blade. Make sure you are holding the head as flat in the horizontal plane as possible. Make one cut through the brain at the level of the cerebellum and one in the front to remove a good chunk of the frontal lobe. It is very important that this second cut is as straight as possible in the vertical plane as this is the surface the brain will stand on when glued to the magnetised block.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gkp","text":"With the brain still immersed in the slush, grab the spatula and carefully scoop the cut parts out. Then carefully separate the useful part of the brain from the base of the skull and gently transfer (do NOT drop) to the 400 mL beaker with the remaining slush of slicing ACSF (which has been bubbling on ice until now). Use the perforated spoon to carefully scoop a pocket in the slush so that the brain remains completely submerged in it. Make sure the bubbling is not too close to the brain.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dr4c","text":"Ideally, the brain brain removal steps should take less than a minute. You can leave the brain to recover for a minute or so in the cold solution, this will ensure to slow down the metabolism and reduce excitotoxicity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"732q8","text":"In the meantime, bring the now empty skull back to the hood and put it in the plastic bag together with the carcass. Properly dispose of the carcass. Close the oxygen flow from the wall and watch the rubber that indicates the flow rate fall to zero. Make sure the isoflurane pump is off. Then close the circuit from the anaesthetic chamber and switch off the scavenging system. Clean the area with ddH2O from any blood or ACSF and wipe with 70% ethanol. Switch the hood ventilation off. Bring the beaker and scissors to the sink. You can finish cleaning up later.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cqkgn","text":"Get the slicing chamber from the freezer. Make sure the magnetised block is dry and the glue hasn't hardened.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvt9s","text":"Use the perforated spoon to carefully lift the brain out of the beaker. Take extra care not to push it against the glass wall. Gently place on the filter paper in the petri dish. Add enough slush of slicing ACSF to cover it. Use the brush to carefully remove any slush that remains stuck to the brain, so that it is free. Re-position the brain so that it sits on the cut you made in the frontal part of the brain (i.e. the cerebellum is facing up to you).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edht3","text":"Put glue on the magnetised block. Make sure there is enough to glue the brain, but not too much that the brain sinks on it.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27u66","text":"With the spatula on your dominant hand and the brush on the other, carefully load the brain on the spatula so that the frontal side faces down (i.e. the bit where the olfactory bulb would have been is in contact with the spatula, and the cerebellum is facing up towards you). Next, carefully lift the brain and gently touch a clean tissue paper to dry out any excess liquid (this will ensure the tissue sticks to the glue). With the brush, gently transfer the brain from the spatula to the magnetised block, placing it on the glue. Use the brush to gently press the cortex down to ensure the brain properly sticks to the magnetised block (only do that if you don't care about the cortex). N.B: be very gentle when transferring the brain to the block. Do not hit the magnetised block against the table (e.g. to force the brain to get pressed against the glue) and avoid any unnecessary mechanical stress to the tissue.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":689,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"181h8","text":"Rapidly use the glass pipette to pour some ice-cold slicing ACSF from the petri dish over the brain - this will both keep the brain cold and harden the glue.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckjup","text":"Carefully mount the magnetised block on the slicing chamber and proceed to fill the chamber with ice-cold slicing ACSF. Use the perforated spoon to protect the brain, so that the slush doesn't fall on it too hard (minimise mechanical stress).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amj4g","text":"Place the slicing chamber on the vibratome and lock it.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

Both provide good quality slices. Note that the steps detailed below will need to be adjusted if a different model or instrument is used.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5jtl5","text":"[OPTION 1 - Slicing with a Leica VT1200S]","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":41}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5b808","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h5c1","text":"Mount the slicing chamber to the vibratome. Fix a small bubbler to the slicing chamber and immerse it in the slicing ACSF to constantly equilibrate the solution with carbogen during slicing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4q511","text":"With the brush, move the slush away from the brain.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8h7au","text":"Lower the blade to horizontal position.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3mf42","text":"Bring the slicing chamber up by pressing \"UP\" until the top of the brain is at the level of the blade.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bms6r","text":"Press the button to move the blade closer to the brain.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38aeb","text":"Set the setting to \"Manual\" and see below for a note on how to slice in this mode.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cp8jt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1kqas","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dg8hf","text":"At the beginning, set the slicing speed to 0.10 mm/s and the amplitude to 1 mm. In the interest of time, slice thicker sections (500 to 900 microns) at this speed until you reach the PAG (or the area of interest).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7bi7e","text":"Once you start to see the Aqueduct, you are getting close to the PAG. Set the slice thickness to 250 microns and speed to 0.05 mm/s (see note above for details, keep the amplitude at 1 mm).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"128j4","text":"While slicing, and as long as you don't need to keep it for your experiment, you can use the brush to carefully get rid of the cortex.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnll8","text":"Once the blade has surpassed the PAG, stop the slicing and bring the slicing chamber 100 microns down (see note above for details).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bore","text":"Use the needle to carefully cut the slice at the bottom to separate it from the brain, making sure you don't touch the sharp end of the blade and without excessively pressing on the blade. Cut away a small piece of tissue from the bottom right side of the slice, so you can orient the slice in the scope and identify the right and left hemispheres.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5aqnp","text":"Using the glass pipette, collect the slice and transfer to the first recovery chamber. According to Bischofberger, et al., 2006 it is better to place the slice upside down from how it was sliced, as the tissue is healthier there.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"629m0","text":"Proceed to obtain the next slice. Repeat the cycle until done. Preparing 250 microns thick slices should give you at least 4-5 usable slices containing the PAG.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b69ih","text":"Try to place the slices on the recovery chamber following the order of slicing. This will allow you to easily locate the coordinates of each slice and keep track of which are the freshest slices.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dklsa","text":"Given that the slicing speed is very low, you can start cleaning the tools and glassware you have finished using. Rinse everything with ddH2O and dry. Put items and tools back to where they belong. Leave the glassware in the drying rack until baking.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"akvpv","text":"Once all the slices have been collected and are being incubated, proceed to clean the vibratome. Carefully remove the blade and thoroughly rinse the blade holder with ddH2O to remove any residues of slicing ACSF (make sure the slicing chamber is still underneath so it collects the water). Remove the slicing chamber and take the magnetised block with the rest of the brain out - use the blade to scrape off the glue and the leftover tissue. Dispose of the blade in a sharps bin. Disassemble the slicing chamber and thoroughly wash with ddH2O. Leave to dry.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3klu6","text":"Using a piece of paper, carefully dry the blade holder and the vibratome. Place a piece of filter paper where the blade slots in, so it absorbes any water left. Lower the blade holder and switch the vibratome off.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8i73f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4llql","text":" ","type":"align-center","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"383eh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5iaq5","text":"In the \"Manual\" mode of the Leica VT1200S, slice as follows: (1) press \"RUN/STOP\" to start slicing, (2) set the desired speed with the top wheel, (3) press \"RUN/STOP\" to stop slicing, (4) use the bottom wheel to bring the slicing chamber \"DOWN\" for 100 microns (i.e. away from the blade, so that you are no longer touching/pushing the brain down and you don't compress the tissue when collecting the slice and retracting the blade), (5) press the button to move the blade back (i.e. away from the brain) until completely out, (6) use the bottom wheel to bring the slicing chamber \"UP\" for 350 microns (i.e. set the desired slice thickness remembering you first moved 100 microns in the opposite direction, so the thickness of this slice will be 250 microns), (7) press \"RUN/STOP\" to resume slicing. Repeat until you collected all the slices you need.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"39801020F85711EC9CFA6D45035ED05C","height":563.1192045454545,"id":262588,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7tl2j","text":"Figure S12. The advantage of using this vibratome is that you do not need to calibrate or align the blade each time, as it uses a ceramic blade that only needs calibrating when you first mount it or replace with a new one. Note that it is also possible to use ceramic blades on the Leica.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb0cc","text":"Mount the slicing chamber, being careful not to touch the blade.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"42p9h","text":"Fix a small bubbler to the slicing chamber and immerse it in the slicing ACSF to constantly equilibrate the solution with carbogen during slicing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26q3e","text":"Select the slicing program (N.B. you need to have created it in advance).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfkv7","text":"With the brush, move the slush away from the brain.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36jgb","text":"Press \"Load Bath\" for a few seconds - the chamber will go up.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4p7i","text":"Press \"Height UP\". Then press \"Advance\", followed by \"Slice ON\" - this will approach the blade to the brain. Stop when close but before touching the brain. This point will be recorded and the blade will go back there each time you press \"Return\" during the slicing process.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7iu5f","text":"The thickness of the slice is predetermined in the program, and in our case it is set to 250 microns.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ah0ir","text":"To obtain each slice, follow the sequence of pressing \"Slice ON - Slice OFF - Return\". Start slicing at a speed of 0.10 mm/s and repeat the sequence as many times as needed until you reach the PAG or area of interest (each cycle goes down a predetermined value, in our case 250 microns).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ai9kc","text":"Once in the area of interest, press \"Slice ON\" and adjust speed to 0.04-0.06 mm/s. Cut away a small piece of tissue from the bottom right side of the slice, so you can orient the slice in the scope and identify the right and left hemispheres.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n2gv","text":"Using the glass pipette, collect the slice and transfer to the first recovery chamber. This will allow you to easily locate the coordinates of each slice and keep track of which are the freshest slices.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gupe","text":"Press \"Return\": this takes the blade back to the starting point, and lowers it 250 microns for the next slice.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s7jj","text":"Proceed to obtain the next slice. Repeat the cycle until done. Preparing 250 microns thick slices should give you at least 4-5 usable slices containing PAG.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63tq4","text":"Given that the slicing speed is very low, you can start cleaning the tools and glassware you have finished using. Rinse everything with ddH2O and dry. Put items and tools back to where they belong. Leave the glassware in the drying rack until baking.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3msdc","text":"Once all the slices have been collected and are being incubated, proceed to clean the vibratome. Press \"Load Bath\" for a few seconds - the chamber will go down.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b715l","text":"Thoroughly rinse the blade with ddH2O to remove any residues of slicing ACSF (make sure the slicing chamber is still underneath so it collects the water).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69dk","text":"Remove the slicing chamber and take the magnetised block with the rest of the brain out - use a blade to scrape off the glue and the leftover tissue.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bujd","text":"Thoroughly clean the slicing chamber with ddH2O. Leave to dry.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etvkg","text":"Using a piece of paper, carefully dry the blade from the back (never touch the sharp edge).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ga6p","text":"Place safety cover on the blade (a red plastic piece with a magnet).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19n2d","text":"Switch vibratome OFF.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1m2bb","text":"[PATH A - Decapitation under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"42jmo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d3cc","text":"In this path, the first recovery chamber contains slicing ACSF (sucrose) and the second recovery chamber contains recording ACSF. Both have been heated to 35°C and equilibrated with carbogen until now. Any bubbles stuck to the net have been removed prior to transferring the slices. Once all the slices have been transferred to the first recovery chamber, proceed with the incubation as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bmubv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5hsuo","text":"Incubate slices for 30 min in slicing ACSF (sucrose) at 35°C, constantly equilibrated with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"injt","text":"After 30 min, carefully remove the second recovery chamber containing recording ACSF from the heating block and place on the bench at room temperature. Use the glass pipette to transfer each slice from the first to the second recovery chamber (from slicing to recording ACSF). Try to minimise any solution carryover when transferring the slices (you want as little sucrose and magnesium as possible added to the new solution).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5c45d","text":"Once all the slices have been transferred to the second recovery chamber, let equilibrate to room temperature for at least 30 more minutes before recording. Constantly equilibrate the solution with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8jeib","text":"If the slices express fluorescence or channelrhodopsin, cover with aluminum foil to protect from ambient light.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8gesq","text":"[PATH B - Perfusion with ACSF under terminal isoflurane anaesthesia]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e8u73","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3cuqo","text":"In this path, the first recovery chamber contains slicing ACSF (NMDG-HEPES) heated to 32°C and constantly equilibrated with carbogen. The second recovery chamber contains holding ACSF (HEPES) and has been heated to 32°C until right before commencing the slicing procedure and then removed from the heating block and placed on the bench at room temperature, constantly equilibrated with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c2cp8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1rduc","text":"In this case, the incubation procedure is slightly different, and the incubation duration is timed independently for each slice.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7ipth","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a1qk4","text":"Incubate each slice for 10-12 min in slicing ACSF (NMDG-HEPES) at 32°C, constantly equilibrated with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"486v7","text":"After the 10-12 min, carefully transfer each slice to the second recovery chamber containing holding ACSF (HEPES), trying to minimise solution carryover. Incubate for at least 1 h at room temperature before recording, constantly equilibrating the solution with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2oaul","text":"If the slices express fluorescence or channelrhodopsin, cover with aluminum foil to protect from ambient light.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5an19","text":"[Common considerations]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1a420","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nfpc","text":"Once the incubation period is over, use the glass pipette to collect the slice you will start recording from and transfer it to the recording chamber in your rig. To stably hold the slice in place you can place a platinum ring with equidistant nylon threads on top.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8mje","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4k9vr","text":"It is important to make sure any holding/slicing solution is washed out before you start your recordings. The slice should be perfused for a sufficiently long time (at least 10 min for a flow rate of 2–5 mL/min) with recording ACSF before starting your experiment. This is important because the different compositions between the recording and the holding/slicing ACSF can difficult obtaining good seals and can affect both excitability and synaptic transmission.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bnbmk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4n4v0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"192nd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1li7r","text":"Regardless of whether Path A or B was followed, the last step before recording is cleaning up. Most points have already been mentioned in the corresponding sections, but they are collected and listed together below.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cjdkr","text":"Tools: thoroughly wash all tools and glassware with ddH2O, making sure to get rid of any blood and salts residues. If any of the tools used during brain extraction have been in contact with glue, use a blade to scrape it off before cleaning and drying the tool.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jiu3","text":"Consumables: properly dispose of any consumables or PPE that have been contaminated by blood or organic tissue using the appropriate bin.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f40n6","text":"Properly dispose of any sharps: needles, blades, and broken glass go to a sharps bin.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":24,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rhku","text":"Properly dispose of the carcass according to the guidelines and protocols in place at the home institution.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6glc6","text":"Clean the bubblestones: rinse with ddH2O and then transfer to a beaker with fresh ddH2O. Immerse them and leave them bubbling for a while. At the end of the day, transfer to a separate beaker with a piece of clean tissue paper at the bottom and leave to dry. Switch carbogen off.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7md8h","text":"Glassware: thoroughly wash all glassware with ddH2O to remove any salt residues from the ACSF solutions. Leave in the rack to dry until the end of the experiment. If possible, proceed to sterilise by baking at 200°C for 2 h, to make sure bacteria can't grow there. If the oven has a timer, you can do this at the end of the day so that it has time to cool down and all glassware is sterile and ready to be used the next morning.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7vb4o","text":"Vibratome: carefully remove the blade and thoroughly rinse the blade holder with ddH2O to remove any salts (make sure the slicing chamber is still underneath so it collects the water). Remove the slicing chamber and take the magnetised block with the rest of the brain out - use the blade to scrape off the glue and the rest of the tissue. Dispose of the blade in a sharps bin. Disassemble the slicing chamber and thoroughly wash with ddH2O. Leave to dry. Using a piece of paper, carefully dry the blade holder and the vibratome. Place a piece of filter paper where the blade slots in, so it dries up any water left. Lower the blade holder and switch vibratome off.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekk63","text":"Bench surfaces: spray some ddH2O on the bench where you have done the brain extraction, the area around the vibratome, and anywhere slicing ACSF may have fallen. Wipe surfaces and dry.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"734pd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7q97d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7qoft","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fl63s","text":"This section highlights some of the key aspects to check when troubleshooting slice quality problems. One important thing to keep in mind when troubleshooting is to only change one thing at a time. In addition, it may be a good idea to invest time testing different combinations of blade, brain extraction method (perfusion or decapitation), solutions, and incubation times to find what works best for your brain area, animal age, and experimental conditions.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d8vi3","text":"[Slicing]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36rno","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"18i7n","text":"An important question when troubleshooting slice quality is: do the slices look good immediately after slicing? What about after the incubation is over? Do they look good immediately after you place them in the recording chamber, or do they already look unhealthy then? The answers to these questions will point you to which of the steps is more likely to be the problem.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3866n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6b936","text":"If the slices look already unhealthy right after slicing (i.e. with a high proportion of very contrasty cells and \"fried eggs\"), you can start by checking the slicing solutions (double check the pH and osmolality or try making a new batch), the vibratome (perhaps it needs servicing or the blade was not properly aligned), or your brain extraction technique (you may need to do it faster or be more careful, or you may need to try intracardially perfusing the animal with slicing ACSF).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1fnva","text":"If the slices appear healthy under the microscope right after slicing, but look unhealthy after incubation, you probably have an issue with either the incubation time, temperature, or solution. It could also be that the recovery chamber is contaminated or the solution is not sufficiently oxygenated.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vukt","text":"Finally, if the slices look perfect right after the incubation, but degrade quickly once you put them in the recording chamber and start your experiment, you may be having issues with the recording ACSF, the temperature in the bath (malfunctioning heater), the oxygenation of the solution, or excitotoxicity of the tissue (recording at room temperature should reduce this).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75ja7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"998qk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8obnr","text":"Other guidelines and advice that may be useful when trying to improve the slicing procedure:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqeab","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9nq9l","text":"When troubleshooting, try to use younger animals first (\u003c6 weeks old if possible). Tissue from young animals is usually more forgiving to the procedure and will help you find what the major problem is.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ec0vi","text":"When extracting the brain, keep the temperature low (0-4°C) and dissect as fast and as careful as you can. Make sure to immerse the head and brain in ice-cold solution at each step to keep as cold as possible.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e2sm2","text":"If you are not already doing it, try to intracardially perfuse the animals with ice-cold slicing ACSF before extracting the brain. This is the best way to clear the blood out of the brain by replacing it with the solution of your choice (e.g. low sodium and calcium and high magnesium and NMDG) to rapidly slow metabolic activity and reduce excitotoxicity. Again, this may work better or worse depending on the brain area and age of the animals you work on, so it is worth comparing the results from intracardial perfusion to those from decapitation before deciding on one approach.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27psh","text":"The exact duration of the recovery period is critical for obtaining the optimal tissue preservation. Try to compare the results obtained with different incubation times to find what works best for your particular brain area and experimental conditions.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4423j","text":"Regardless of whether you perform your recordings at room or physiological temperature, the incubation step at room temperature is crucial as it allows the slices to recover from spine sprouting, which occurs when slicing (see Edwards, et al., 1989).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7tgae","text":"If possible, check the slice quality of a colleague using the same equipment and solutions than you. This can help you rule out problems with carbogen, water, or slicing machine. However, beware of differences between brain areas (the same procedure can give an excellent quality for visual cortex and kill all your cells in the periaqueductal gray).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"652th","text":"[Vibratome]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0hv7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rc4o","text":"It is very important that the machine you use to prepare slices is of a high quality and in excellent condition.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk46b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37pm3","text":"If possible, try to have the vibratome you use routinely serviced.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8htn7","text":"Always calibrate the z displacement of the blade to make sure it is not inflicting unwanted mechanical damage on your slices.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3lq0c","text":"Try using ceramic blades, but beware they may or may not improve your slice quality depending on the brain region you study. If you opt to use them, replace the blade if old or blunted.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pr0u","text":"Change the angle or the speed at which you slice - again, the usefulness of this may depend on the brain region you work on. The structure of the periaqueductal gray makes the coronal slice the best option, but this may not be the case for neighbouring areas.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t2te","text":"If you are not sure your vibratome is the problem, you could try to find a colleague in a neighouring laboratory who currently gets good slices and ask whether you may use their machine to rule out there is an issue with yours.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1o85e","text":"[Solutions]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ikf5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c383i","text":"If working with animals over 8 weeks old, try to use solutions optimised for adult brain tissue such as NMDG- or Choline-based ACSF, where NMDG-Cl or Choline-Cl replaces NaCl. Together with a low temperature, this will help reduce excitotoxicity. It may be worth comparing the results between the high sucrose slicing solution and the NMDG/Choline solution in your hands.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1e1k","text":"Adding 20 mM HEPES can effectively provide stronger pH buffering in the physiological range and prevent excessive edema.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5783l","text":"You can also try adding supplements for energy supply and antioxidant function. Myo-inositol and sodium pyruvate provide additional entry points into cellular metabolism, whereas ascorbic acid, thiourea, and N-acetyl-L-cysteine (a cell-permeable glutathione precursor) help reduce oxidative stress.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qsor","text":"Use purified water that is free of contaminants such as trace metals. Impurities like these are often found in distilled water sources and cause damage to the slices and can even convert anti-oxidants such as ascorbate into pro-oxidants.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9td1h","text":"Make sure your solutions are fresh, ideally less than 24 h but certainly not older than a week.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpidf","text":"Minimise carryover when transferring slices between solutions: an extreme way of doing this would be having an intermediate beaker (so you transfer the slice to the first beaker, and then from there to the second) so that any carryover is diluted.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ag05r","text":"If you suspect your solutions are the cause of low quality slices, you could try to find a colleague in a neighouring laboratory who currently gets good slices and ask whether you could use some of their solutions for a test. Alternatively, you could ask whether you could use a spare slice from them to check they are equally happy in your rig and theirs.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fhlhv","text":"[Water]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vm05","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cm4ju","text":"Another usual suspect when troubleshooting slice quality issues is the water you use to prepare solutions. It is possible that the water source has become contaminated or the filters saturated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l807","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aectv","text":"If in doubt, and if possible, you can purchase commercially available ultrapure ddH2O and make fresh solutions with it. One of the first things to rule out should always be the batch of ACSF you used.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6997k","text":"Make sure all the solutions and concentrated stocks are made with ultrapure, double-distilled water.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rpn4","text":"It is advisable to regularly submit samples from your water system for analysis to check for bacterial contamination and to compare the quality to UltraPure (e.g. Severn Biotech) and Molecular Grade Sterile Water (e.g. Corning).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b245u","text":"If using a water purification system, ensure it is properly maintained: replace filters, run a cleaning and sterilization cycle, replace UV lamps, etc.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1qi2f","text":"[Salts]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"604pr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bb1c","text":"Although infrequent, it is possible that the salts and chemicals you use to prepare the solutions have gone bad or you received a contaminated batch.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m9qo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rmij","text":"Some salts (such as sodium pyruvate) can go bad quicker than others. Keep track of the opening date and replace if older than 3-6 months.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ujh8","text":"If nothing else works, you can try to replace all salts for new ones and make fresh solutions.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2n1jt","text":"[Glassware]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"835u8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"91kq4","text":"A very important point is to avoid bacterial contamination and salt build up in your glassware.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8unoq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f2nog","text":"To minimise this risk, thoroughly clean the glassware and tools you use to prepare solutions, with special emphasis on the recovery chambers.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5jms","text":"If possible, have a separate set of glassware specifically dedicated to your slice work.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27lh9","text":"If you dispose of an oven, sterilise the glassware by baking it for 2 h at 200°C before every use.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5nrn7","text":"It is also possible to use a solution with 0.1 M nitric acid to help get rid of any salt build up on the glass, but make sure you thoroughly clean with ultrapure ddH2O afterwards.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ne02","text":"[Carbogen]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jdm1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4qfc","text":"It is also possible that the solutions and slices are not sufficiently oxygenated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejc4g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8kpp","text":"Set the bubbling really high whenever possible to ensure you oxygenate the tissue as much as possible, and always equilibrate solutions for 20-30 min prior to use.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e94lf","text":"If not sure, test the carbogen outlets to ensure the mixture has the right concentration (95% O2 and 5% CO2).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1utv","text":"If using tanks, make sure that the current one is not empty or that you did not get a bad batch.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"il1g","text":"[Osmolality, pH, and temperature]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33pc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0rb1","text":"Make sure the osmometer and pH meter are properly calibrated and clean.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pcvt","text":"Always check the osmolality and pH of your solutions, as both values may change after 30 minutes of bubbling. When possible, cover the beakers and recovery chambers with parafilm to minimise evaporation and loss of solution when bubbling.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8c5gn","text":"If you need to reduce osmolality of the slicing solution, try to change the amount of sucrose or NMDG/Choline, so that you don't modify the other ion concentration.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edrgr","text":"pH is temperature dependent and slicing ACSF can turn acidic after bubbling for 30 min on ice (0-4°C). Do check if that is the case and readjust if necessary so it is as close to 7.3-7.4 as possible. A low pH will certainly have an effect on the quality of the slices.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16n6k","text":"If possible, use an external thermometer to double-check the temperature in the bath, recovery chamber, and recording chamber is what you are expecting.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21ppf","text":"Surround the slicing chamber with ice and keep it in the freezer until use to keep the temperature as low as possible.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"esiao","text":"[PFA contamination]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2vmi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5p5rf","text":"Do your best to avoid and rule out an accidental PFA contamination in your tubing, bench area, glassware, tools. {"blocks":[{"key":"94nr6","text":"[Example of a slice troubleshooting cycle]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgin9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75gkq","text":"Sometimes, you may be at a loss as to what is affecting the quality of your slices. In such occasions, a systematic approach or knowing what worked for others may help identify the issue. As an example, we tried the following changes to solve our slice quality issues after a series of bad experiments:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82sat","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"72l8a","text":"First, we switched to using commercially available bottled ultrapure water to make solutions (a previous troubleshooting cycle ended when discovering a problem with the water source we were using), and proceeded to clean and calibrate the pH meter and osmometer.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bltn","text":"We ordered new glassware and thoroughly washed it, and we started baking it to sterilise it.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9elc2","text":"We replaced all bubblestones and tubing, renewed all salts, made new stocks (e.g. 2.5 M KCl and 1.25 M NaH2PO4), made new recovery and recording chambers, and flushed the tubing of the perfusion system in the rig with EtOH and ddH2O.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1uvn9","text":"We tested the water source and carbogen outlets, and serviced the vibratome. We asked to use a new vibratome from a neighouring laboratory until ours could be serviced.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dis65","text":"We started intracardially perfusing our animals with ACSF, as many studies have shown this helps preserve the tissue in better condition (especially in adult animals over 6-8 weeks old), and tried more protective solutions (NMDG and Choline based). Effectively, we moved from Path A to Path B of this protocol.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4pq6","text":"We watched how several colleagues sliced and compared their approach and solutions to ours. We introduced further recommendations such as testing and adjusting the pH right before use (ACSF solutions turned acidic when cold).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m2bq","text":"We compared different approaches by slicing pairs of younger animals (~4 weeks old) and changing one thing at a time: one perfused vs. one decapitated, one with a longer incubation vs. one with a shorter, one sliced with a vibratome vs. one sliced with a different machine, one with our usual solution vs. one with a new recipe, one with the usual blade vs. one with a new ceramic blade, etc.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpkpm","text":"After a series of rounds of testing, and after always sticking with the best option of each comparison, we found we obtained the best improvements after servicing the vibratome (it turned out it had a malfunctioning piece), changing the solutions (NMDG and HEPES holding gave significantly better results than sucrose), and intracardially perfusing the animals.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"58btb","text":"[Proper positioning of the inflow and outflow in the recording chamber]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":71}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9qjo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98nm4","text":"Finding the optimal position for the inflow and outflow will ensure the bath level remains stable throughout your experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9e1s2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1859h","text":"If using a needle as an outflow/suction, make sure the end is not completely immersed but it rather has half the tip immersed and the other half resting above the bath level (Figure S14).
